results.title: 100 years: the Australian story
results.creator_credit: Deborah Masters, Sue Spencer and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: A documentary of Australia, one of the world’s oldest democracies, this extensive and thorough series traces Australian political history. Themes of empire, independence, multiculturalism and indigenous Australia make up this enlightening series. Politicians, activists, experts and everyday Australians contributed to this powerful, educational documentary.

results.title: [Watching television]
results.brief_description: Short comic film made in 1958 by Graham Foster and friends to send to his relatives in New Zealand. Structured as ‘a mini sitcom’ the film features a group of friends engrossed in the act of watching television and has a voiceover by Foster. Features television advertising from the late 1950s. Companion piece to ‘A Kiwi in Exile’.

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film shows a family holiday, including scenes of a campground beside a river and a trip to Sydney. It includes some great footage of the Sydney Opera House under construction, seen from Sydney Harbour.

This film was made on Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 weatherboard house with roses in the front yard
00:00:54:00 a campground with tents and caravans
00:02:34:00 an Aboriginal child looking at the camera shyly
00:04:36:00 the Sydney Opera House under construction, seen from the harbour
00:05:41:00 on a ferry across Sydney Harbour

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This short film consists of a brief snapshot of a wedding, with some great shots of pink bridesmaids dresses and a wedding dress of the era.

This film was made on Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:15:00 two women in pink bridesmaids dresses with matching gloves and headpieces leaving a suburban house
00:00:50:00 the bride in her wedding dress follows them into the car
00:01:24:00 the couple at their wedding

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film contains great footage of a trip to Japan, including urban scenes, Japanese cars, visits to temples and socialising with Japanese locals.

This film was made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 aeroplanes on the tarmac
00:00:14:00 view from the plane as it takes off, including the Sydney Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge
00:01:32:00 coastline from the plane
00:01:45:00 view from the plane, Bali International Airport Ngurah Rai
00:02:20:00 scenes in Japan
00:03:00:00 feeding the deer, probably at Nara
00:03:30:00 Tōdai-ji, Nara (temple complex)
00:04:05:00 Bishamonten statue, Tōdai-ji, Nara
00:04:45:00 in the forest and visiting temples
00:05:41:00 a cute Japanese toddler in pink overalls
00:07:35:00 driving through city streets, views from the window of a bus
00:08:55:00 groups of Japanese schoolchildren having their photo taken at a temple
00:11:17:00 a fish pond with a waterfall (Ninomaru Garden and pond, Nijo Castle, Kyoto)
00:11:35:00 people viewing didactic map of Nijo Castle complex, Kyoto
00:14:00:00 cable car on a busy city street
00:15:08:00 neon sign ‘Matsushita Electric’
00:17:53:00 orderly city streets filled with traffic
00:20:10:00 View of Mt Fuji
00:20:55:00 close-ups of group of Japanese friends at dinner, all laughing and pulling faces at the camera
00:22:43:00 bright neon billboards at night
00:24:00:00 Coca-Cola billboard
00:25:02:00 view of city buildings from a plane landing
00:26:00:00 views across the harbour of a city (possibly Hong Kong)
00:28:34:00 double decker cable cars covered in advertising

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 15]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film contains footage of a visit to the Gresswell Sanatorium in Mont Park, Victoria, which at the time housed and treated male patients with tuberculosis. Mont Park was an area north-east of Melbourne comprising several health institutions, including the Gresswell Sanatorium which was named after Dan Gresswell, a public health administrator. The film provides an insightful look at life in the sanatorium, including recreational activities and health care.

This film was made on Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 great example of a handpainted sign reading ‘Repatriation Sanatorium, Drive Slow, Gresswell Sanatorium’
00:00:13:00 a 1940s style bus with logo ‘Heidelberg Motor Omnibus Service Pty. Ltd.’
00:00:40:00 a woman in 1940s style dress disembarks the bus
00:01:22:00 three men walking down the road
00:01:58:00 a man using a grinding wheel in a work shed
00:03:11:00 meal time at the sanatorium
00:04:07:00 a cheeky group of people in conversation, with several poking their tongue out to the camera
00:06:18:00 playing cricket with branches amongst the trees
00:07:22:00 a patient being treated with an injection and valve, presumably to relieve air from the lung, a common treatment for tuberculosis at the time
00:08:56:00 nurse in uniform of the era with a long veil

results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is a snapshot into suburban family life, showing a child’s birthday party.

This film was made on Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:20:00 boy with a birthday cake
00:01:50:00 group of boys playing and wrestling

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 14]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is predominantly comprised of a trip through the Snowy Mountains, including some lovely footage of the landscape.

This film was made on Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 dancers doing a hula performance and getting men in suits to join in
00:01:22:00 driving through countryside
00:01:33:00 road sign ‘Adaminaby’
00:01:35:00 large information sign and map for the Snowy Mountains Scheme
00:02:44:00 roads through the Snowy Mountains
00:03:41:00 views of the Tumut Pond dam

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 13]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film contains three distinct scenes. The first is footage of an arts and crafts show, including jewellery, pottery and sculpture on display; the second is a man weaving a basket; and the third shows children and adolescents in a gymnastics class, practising somersaults, cartwheels and back flips.

This film was made on Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 displays of jewellery and pottery
00:00:55:00 a girl in white cat eye glasses
00:01:51:00 a man basket weaving
00:02:28:00 a group of children and adolescents practising somersaults in a gymnastics class
00:04:05:00 cartwheels and back flips
